title: NIS
text: Working National Inpatient Sample (NIS) database can challenging due size (>7M records per year 170+ variables) limited support non-proprietary statistical software packages. goal readHCUP make easier researchers focus research, loading data R. mind, readHCUP’s read_nis() allows researchers read datasets single function call.

title: NIS
text: purchased NIS dataset HCUP, can read NIS dataset (.ASC file) R using single function, read_nis(). following code uses synthetic NIS 2019 dataset (avoid publishing real data) show read NIS datasets R: path dataset year produced need read dataset R save tibble. NOTE: current method reading data using read_nis() comes readr package. future, additional support methods read.table

title: NIS
text: default, read_nis() automatically returns corrected version data. example, HCUP released corrections PCLASS_ORPROC NIS 2019 2020 datasets. Usually, ’d need download CSV file corrections update values dataset. process can bit hassle 7M+ records, corrections automatically applied using read_nis(). Note: corrections applied, KEY_NIS PCLASS_ORPROC need included dataset. included, read_nis() still return data, receive warning corrections applied. don’t want corrections automatically applied, use corrected = FALSE:
code: # Read dataset the first 10 records of the dataset without corrections. df <- read_nis("NIS_2019_test_data.ASC", 2019, n_max = 10, corrected = FALSE)

previous_headings: Working with the NIS dataset > Corrected datasets
title: NIS
text: structure NIS dataset can change year, means read_nis() needs updated support NIS dataset. can find list readHCUP’s supported datasets running following: data name dataset year dataset_file_name file name provided HCUP Central Distributor dataset supported, receive error message: ’re working dataset currently supported, please open issue GitHub, ’ll work adding list supported datasets.
code: supported_datasets #> $data #> [1] "NIS 2016" "NIS 2017" "NIS 2018" "NIS 2019" "NIS 2020" #>  #> $dataset_file_name #> [1] "NIS_2016_CORE"    "NIS_2017_CORE"    "NIS_2018_CORE"    "NIS_2019_CORE_V2" #> [5] "NIS_2020_CORE_V2" df_error <- read_nis("nis", 2040) #> Error in read_nis("nis", 2040): This is not a currently supported dataset.  #>   A list of supported datasets can be found using: View(supported_datasets)

previous_headings: Working with the NIS dataset > Corrected datasets
title: NIS
text: NIS dataset 150 variables, covered detail HCUP’s website. descriptions() function allows get list variable descriptions:
code: d_list <- descriptions("nis", 2019) head(d_list) #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   variable    labels                                             #>   <chr>       <chr>                                              #> 1 AGE         Age in years at admission                          #> 2 AGE_NEONATE Neonatal age (first 28 days after birth) indicator #> 3 AMONTH      Admission month                                    #> 4 AWEEKEND    Admission day is a weekend                         #> 5 DIED        Died during hospitalization                        #> 6 DISCWT      NIS discharge weight

title: Authors and Citation
text: Jon Bryant. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Bryant J (2024). readHCUP: Easily load work HCUP datasets. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://jonbry.github.io/readHCUP/, https://github.com/jonbry/readHCUP.
code: @Manual{,   title = {readHCUP: Easily load and work with HCUP datasets},   author = {Jon Bryant},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://jonbry.github.io/readHCUP/},   url = {https://github.com/jonbry/readHCUP}, }

title: Easily load and work with HCUP datasets
text: readHCUP makes easy read work datasets Healthcare Cost Utilization Project (HCUP). readHCUP’s functions designed work ASC files directly, need preprocess data supported datasets. number supported datasets currently limited package beta, datasets added soon. currently supported datasets: NIS 2016-2021 current import method utilizes readr, additional import functions (data.table, etc) added near future. Please feel free create issue questions, feedback, feature requests.

title: Easily load and work with HCUP datasets
text: can install development version readHCUP GitHub :

title: Easily load and work with HCUP datasets
code: library(readHCUP)  # The following uses an example NIS dataset  # Read theNIS dataset df <- read_nis("inst/data/NIS_2019_test_data.ASC", 2019)  # Read only the first 5 observations df_5 <- read_nis("NIS_2019_test_data.ASC", 2019, n_max = 5)  # Read in only the first three diagnostic codes (columns) of the first 10 observations df_3dx <- read_nis("NIS_2019_test_data.ASC", 2019,                    col_select = c("I10_DX1", "I10_DX2", "I10_DX3"),                    n_max = 10)

title: Easily load and work with HCUP datasets
text: default, read_nis() automatically returns corrected version data. example, HCUP released corrections PCLASS_ORPROC NIS 2019 2020 datasets. Usually, ’d need download csv file corrections update values dataset. can bit hassle 7M+ records, corrections automatically applied using read_nis(). Note: order corrections applied, KEY_NIS PCLASS_ORPROC need included dataset. included, read_nis() still return data receive warning corrections applied. don’t want corrections automatically applied, use corrected = FALSE:
code: # Read dataset the first 10 records of the dataset without corrections. df <- read_nis("NIS_2019_test_data.ASC", 2019, n_max = 10, corrected = FALSE)

title: Easily load and work with HCUP datasets
text: structure NIS dataset can change year, means read_nis() needs updated support NIS dataset. can find list readHCUP’s supported datasets running following: supported_datasets includes: data column name dataset year dataset_file_name column file name provided HCUP Central Distributor

title: Easily load and work with HCUP datasets
text: NIS dataset 150 variables, covered detail HCUP’s website. descriptions() function allows get list variable descriptions:

text: Return table variables descriptions

title: Return a table of variables and their descriptions — descriptions
Return a table of variables and their descriptions — descriptions
text: dataset dataset (currently supporting NIS). year dataset year.

title: Return a table of variables and their descriptions — descriptions
text: tibble consisting variable names descriptions.

title: Return a table of variables and their descriptions — descriptions
code: # The descriptions for the first 5 variables var_desc <- descriptions("nis", 2019) head(var_desc, 5) #> # A tibble: 5 × 2 #>   variable    labels                                             #>   <chr>       <chr>                                              #> 1 AGE         Age in years at admission                          #> 2 AGE_NEONATE Neonatal age (first 28 days after birth) indicator #> 3 AMONTH      Admission month                                    #> 4 AWEEKEND    Admission day is a weekend                         #> 5 DIED        Died during hospitalization

title: Read in NIS dataset — read_nis
text: NIS datasets can challenging work .ASC files include information variables, labels, NA values. read_nis() function reads .ASC file returns R object correct variable names NA values.

title: Read in NIS dataset — read_nis
code: read_nis(   file,   year,   import_method = "readr",   col_select = NULL,   n_max = Inf,   corrected = TRUE )

title: Read in NIS dataset — read_nis
text: file Path NIS dataset file. year year dataset. import_method function import data. default readr. col_select Columns include results. Columns can selected name numerical column index. n_max maximum number rows/observations. default set rows (Inf). corrected official corrections applied data. default set TRUE.

title: Read in NIS dataset — read_nis
text: Returns tibble

title: Read in NIS dataset — read_nis
code: # Read in the example NIS 2019 dataset. if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ NIS_2019_df <- read_nis("NIS_2019_test_data.ASC", 2019) } # }  # Read in the first 5 observations of the example NIS 2019 dataset. if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ NIS_2019_df <- read_nis("NIS_2019_test_data.ASC", 2019, n_max = 5) } # }  # Read in the first three diagnostic codes un the first 10 observations of # the example NIS 2019 dataset. if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ NIS_2019_df <- read_nis("NIS_2019_test_data.ASC", 2019, col_select = c("I10_DX1", "I10_DX2", "I10_DX3"), n_max = 10)  # This can also be done with: NIS_2019_df <- read_nis("NIS_2019_test_data.ASC", 2019, col_select = 19:21, n_max = 10) } # }
